answers.question: Have you participated in a previous Gitcoin Grants Round? If so, please name the rounds or link the builder profile associated with previous rounds.

answers.answer:
Everything on Kiwi - since Day 1 - is 100% open source. 

Devs can look into our front-end, back-end and P2P protocol code. 

We also do a lot of R&D work - so far we shipped key delegation, implemented passkeys and designed onchain ads and everything is publicly available for other projects to use.

We are also running an open devs chat where we discuss our technical decisions. Everyone can join, ask questions and contribute.
answers.question: How does your project contribute to the growth of the OSS ecosystem? Please provide specific examples of how your application enhances or expands the current ecosystem.

answers.answer:
Kiwi is a space for people who care about Ethereum, beyond its price.

It’s an app where everyone can follow the most important ETH ideas and projects without Twitter noise. 

Every month our community of 100+ Ethereum power users goes through hundreds of tweets, blogposts, dashboards, newsletters and products, to surface the ones that stand out. 

Everyone can join them and start sharing, upvoting, and discussing the links with our community. Everyone can also just read Kiwi and join our 2,000+ monthly readers.

So Kiwi is basically Ethereum Hacker News. It is differentiated because other projects are either curated by one person (Telegram channels like Cookie Reads) or focused on different type of content (social networks like Farcaster, Lens).
answers.question: What features or use cases does your dApp/App present? How is it differentiated?

answers.answer:
We found out that comments are the most important element of our app, because they help readers better understand ETH ideas, dashboards and products.

So right now we want to improve the comments - so far we shipped emoji reactions and notifications, and now we want to improve the speed and stability of commenting, to make the experience closer to real-time Telegram conversations. 

This is technically challenging and will take at least a few weeks - if not months - of development.

Since there are only the two of us and we want to ship fast, there are also some bugs and smaller improvements that we need to fix to make our users happier.
answers.question: What are your plans for further development, and how will the grant funds be used to achieve these goals?

For any project deploying smart contracts on blockchain networks, please list all your deployer addresses and their corresponding blockchain networks. Use this format for each entry: [deployer_address], [chain_id]—for example, 0x123abc..., 42161 (This represents a deployer address on the Arbitrum network). Please include a separate line for each unique deployer address and blockchain combination.

project.title: Kiwi News
project.description:
Kiwi is a space for people who care about Ethereum, beyond its price. 

It’s a place where everyone can follow the most important ETH ideas and projects without Twitter noise. They can also connect with other Ethereum power users through deep, nuanced discussions.

We've been building Kiwi since 2023 because we believe that Ethereum should have a decentralized 'online magazine', where you can become smarter every time you read it.

That's why every month our community of 100+ Ethereum power users goes through hundreds of tweets, blogposts, dashboards, newsletters and products, to surface the ones that stand out. 

Everyone can join them and start sharing, upvoting, and discussing the links with our community. Everyone can also just read Kiwi and join our 2,000+ monthly readers.

We care about building IRL connections between our curators and users so we have been organizing meetups during main ETH conferences in Berlin, Paris, Warsaw, Bangkok & Istanbul.

Since we care about Ethereum, we also organize writing contests that touch on important ETH ideas. Like the one we did about L2s with Lens (https://paragraph.xyz/@kiwi-updates/pluralistic-future-of-l2s-results), where we ended up receiving 20+ submissions. 

Some of the submissions came from people such as Marek (Co-Founder @ Celo), Simon de la Rouviere (Co-inventor of ERC20), and Jason Chaskin (Researcher @ Ethereum Foundation). And one of the contest prompts came from Vitalik.

We also care deeply about decentralization. That's why all Kiwi content - 13,000+ links and 4,000+ comments - is stored on a P2P network. 

This means that everyone can build their own client, like on Farcaster or Lens. There's been already alt client like kiwinews.lol (kiwinews.lol) and search engines like KNSearch (https://knsearch.x4901.xyz/).

Also, everything on Kiwi is open source: our front-end, back-end and protocol code. So the fruits of our R&D work on key delegation, onchain ads, and implementing passkeys is publicly available for other projects to use.

Since we wanted to stay independent, we refused to take VC money, and since the beginning we have been living off grants, a bit of revenue, and our savings. So far we received grants from Optimism Retro Funding, Octant, Gitcoin OSS rounds, Farcaster, Purple, and a few more.

So if you care about changing the way people think about Ethereum and helping builders get the best ideas, please consider supporting Kiwi.

You can check our app on news.kiwistand.com

You can also read more about us here: kiwistand.github.io/kiwi-docs

Or go through our GitHub repo: github.com/attestate/kiwistand
